simplesect.para: (Remember to note the temptations/perils of over-automation, that is, attempts to automate things that really require human attention. Technical infrastructure is important, but what makes a free software project work is the care -- and intelligent application of that care -- by the humans involved. One good example is the FAQ-o-Matic disaster. Search for other examples of over-automation, for example, in use of bug tracking systems.)

sect1.title: What a Project Needs
sect1.para: Project web site, source code repository, mailing lists, bug tracker, IRC, and other communications forums.

para.remark: (Talk about the importance of adhering to the standards. Describe and reference them. Use cvs2svn as an example of how *not* to do it.)

sect1.title: Version Control
sect1.remark: (Talk about the importance of doing it, describe it as a communications medium, list the choices, point out that CVS is the safe choice right now. Talk about commit emails, setting reply-to.)

sect1.title: What's Out There For Free?
sect1.para: Describe various sites that provide some of these services for free, such as SourceForge, Savannah, Freenode, etc. Evaluate pros/cons of each, compare with roll-your-own solutions.

para.remark: A *perfect* example of one disadvantage of using a canned site: the handling of generated files. You don't want them in version control, because they're generated. On the other hand, you can't make arbitrary scripts run on the server, because you don't own the server. Use the SVN FAQ as a cautionary tale.
(Mention the survey by Haggen So, at http://www.ibiblio.org/fosphost/ and http://www.ibiblio.org/fosphost/exhost.htm. It's pretty amazing!)
